response.answer_text: Yes, it is possible to have parallel worlds. There is no pratical proof for this statement but there are many theoretical opnions and assumptions. We have seen multiple dimensions or heard the concept of it in many movies or TV series like Dr Strange, Ultimate Spiderman, The flash, Avengers Endgame etc. According to MCU's Dr Strange and Avengers Endgame, there is a multi verse. And the alternate timelines are created when we change the past. But there will be no change in the present timeline. For example, in Avengers Endgame, when Thanos and his army comes from past to present, present Nebula kills the past Nebula, yet the Nebula of the present is alive. In this way two parallel worlds are created, in one Nebula is dead and in another she isn't. It is like if I go back in time and kill one of my friend, my friend won't be alive in the future of my past timeline but he will be alive when I come back to the present time. So there are two worlds, one in which my friend is not alive and the other in which he is. This theory is completely contrary to The Flash theory. In flash, if you change the past, your future will be changed. Parallel worlds in flash are shown as a different earth in this series. Like there is universe, and in this universe there are many galaxies and in each galaxy there is planet Earth. In Earth 1, if I am dauntless in another earth I will be timid. And in Ultimate Spiderman there are just parallel worlds similar to flash but there are no multiple earths. Its just parallel worlds where I am male in one world and female is another. In one world, the cities are highly sophisticated and in another it is not. What I believe is there are parallel worlds like Ultimate spiderman. And these parallel worlds emerge because of the decisions we make in our lives. Every day we gets choices, what we opt will be our reality and what we didn't will be our alternate reality. For instance a girl comes and proposes me and I accept, this is my present reality and the alternate is the one where I didn't accept her. And I would love to travel between parallel worlds and see my other selves. My biggest fantacy is to meet my female version. The MULTIVERSE theory states that the universe we live in may not be the only one in extentance. In fact, our universe could be just one of an infinite number of universes making up a "multiverse." There are several theories explaining how multiverses are formed - like the extension theory, inflation, parallel universes, daughter universes, mathematical universes etc. I will not attempt to explain all.  It is  vast subject. Since we are only looking at the possibilities of their existence, we need to take a look at what quantum mechanics says in this regard. According to quantum mechanics, 'objective reality' does not exist. What are seeing are only probabilities that are converging into a certain configuration, and all other possible realities must exist in a multiverse. There are two main theories as to what these different universes may contain. The first proposes that the same matter and the physical laws that exist in our universe prevail in these universes too. However, due the varying degrees with which they were created, it allowed for these other universes to have every possible combination of particles available - meaning - the continents would probably be where our oceans are, and so on. The second idea is that the other universes may not even operate in the same way as ours does. There could even be different physical laws and spatial dimensions. The first model allows the idea that any given person can exist at the same time in more than one place. If  we are able to find out how to travel to these other universes, we would be able to ‘meet’ our other selves - a'la "FRINGE" the American SciFi TV serial in which travelling to a parallel universe is shown. In one world you could be a scientist, in another world a Formula-1 racer, in yet another world a Golf champion, and so forth. The options would be virtually limitless. Mathematical discoveries made by scientists positively state that multiple universes exist.  Parallel universe theory was first proposed by an American physicist, Hugh Everett in the mid-1950s. The theory attempts to solve many of the mysteries of quantum mechanics. Everett claimed that the universe splits every time a new physical opportunity is explored.  There is a possible alternative outcome in the alternate universe for each event occurred in our own universe.  This theory has gained great acceptance not only from quantum physicists, but also from past life regression therapists. I personally dismiss parallel universe theory as scientific fiction, as the idea is quite unearthly as of now. But many well- known researchers are propagating this theory these days.  It is gaining new supporters all the time. I fully agree, new research studies may unveil fresh evidence. Already, scientists at Oxford University have offered a mathematical answer to this controversial theory. This research shows that Dr Hugh Everett was on the right track. So much so, this research is one of the most important developments in the history of science.  The eminent American theoretical physicist Richard Feynman once noted: "I think I can safely say that nobody understands quantum mechanics."

There is practically no book, no publication about cosmology, where you don't have to drive the road to the parallel universe at some point. Because back there lies the solution to a problem most people don't know anything about. So the point is that you don't understand why the world is the way it is. Quite simply. Why is the world the way it is? And if you take a closer look at it: Why is there such an incredibly finely tuned nature, a universe that can't be any different, otherwise everything would collapse? The fine tuning thing goes back to a work by Stephen Hawking from the 70s. Where he calculated: If I would disturb the universe a bit at the beginning, a bit more energy or a bit less energy, what would that mean for the long-term development of the universe? The fact is that when a universe has a lot of mass, it collapses again. After initial expansion, mass, i.e. gravity, would retract the universe and then collapse back to 0. And so there's the so-called cyclic universe. There's the idea that it always repeats itself. Then there's the other variant: A universe begins with an expansion, but it's too light that this expansion can be brought back again by its own gravity and races apart! And then there's the variant in between. Where everything is exactly right. So the universe will just start to expand and will go on and on and on and on. In this universe it just goes on and on. And what Hawking found out is that you have to fine-tune the universe. It looks like a ballpoint pen is standing on its tip, but if a ballpoint pen is standing on its tip and the tip is not standing on a table and stops. The probability that the pen will stop now is almost 0. Of course there is no such thing. It doesn't just stand on a plate and stop, it stands on a razor blade. And this razor blade stands with its blade again on a razor blade on another razor blade on a razor blade on a razor blade. One could get the impression that there are 10^55 razor blades standing on top of each other and at the very top the ballpoint pen is standing. And does not fall over. The universe is so finely tuned. This is of course a provocation for a scientist. That can't be! There's always room for manoeuvre. And the others said: Nope, necessary. It could be that there are 10^500 parallel universes. Yes! One universe is too heavy. Falling down again. The other one is too light and flies apart. And so the one in which we live is the one where the combination of natural constants and laws of nature has led to exactly what we are today. This is how the idea arises that there could have been others outside our universe, at least in terms of time. So without the beginning of a universe there's no time. But we could say that there is a multiverse. So a super-universe, in which individual universes would arise. And that's how they would have come into being. Or they were created at the same time as ours. Only somehow differently, somewhere else, so that they didn't survive it in any case. As I said, some of them have flown apart. The others have collapsed. There was actually a completely empirical reason, because there are a number of observations that cannot be explained any differently than with a kind of over-expansion. This over-expansion is called "inflationary expansion". What is inflation anyway? Inflation is over-expansion. So there's the normal expansion and then there's the sudden over-accelerated expansion of the whole universe. And that was clearly after the Big Bang. The big bang is after 10 to 43 seconds and the inflation was at 10^-30 seconds. So there has passed an eternity in between. And there the universe had felt quite well before actually the whole time and then it was disturbed. And then it made Booom! And the universe flies apart by 50 orders of magnitude in 0 time. What kind of universe is that? We observe that the universe is obviously flat as a board. So really as flat as a board. So apart from such small wells - they are caused by the presence of matter. This is known from the general theory of relativity. The presence of matter bends space-time. Yes, where there is a lot of mass, there is spacetime. But if you average it all away, then it's on the long run, as it's so nicely called, it's flat as a board. A three-dimensional body that is flat, that is flat everywhere. It could be a sphere that is so oversized, that you can measure it locally, within a few billion light years, because the universe is so huge. And so the idea of inflation came into the world. But if that's the case, you have to ask yourself: is there any mechanism that can explain it? Yes. There is. To translate that into our world: It's about subcooled water. So water is normal, when it gets cold below 0°C water starts to freeze from top to bottom. Is clear. If it becomes colder and colder, it will freeze through sometime. But if you cool it down very, very, very slowly so that the water doesn't notice it, then it stays liquid. The world record is well under -20°C. But of course it is wrong. And what happens to the wrong thing? The smallest disturbance freezes the water. And this freezing naturally releases energy. What used to be the free energy the water molecules still had, now they are locked in crystal, now suddenly this energy is released. And this energy would have been released in the universe. It would have caused the universe to over-expand. And perhaps another tiny hint: the idea of inflation was based on an idea. The idea of scalar fields. So a scalar field is a field that is everywhere. Direction-independent everywhere. That's what we found. Since 2012 we definitely know: There is such a scalar field. It's called a Higgs field. This is an example of a field that could have made this transition in the early cosmos of inflationary expansion. And that would make a great connection between the greatest and the smallest. So elementary particle physics and cosmology. We would have reconnected that now. That's great. And maybe we would have got an idea that it is actually possible that such a fine tuning actually leads at the beginning to the fact that once you put such a ballpoint pen on a razor blade in a real universe, it stops there. That's unbelievable. But of course it's also clear that if the whole thing had taken place again in a superuniverse, then there could also be other universes that are currently expanding parallel to our universe. And they collapsed relatively quickly under their own weight. Others have also stopped for a long time. Expanding somewhere. What is outside our universe and what was before the beginning of the universe, we cannot answer everything. Because we are empirical scientists. We try to gain insights empirically, i.e. with the help of experience. These findings always take place in such a way that one tries to measure something and to observe. And in this way we know today: it could be that there are parallel universes. There is our universe. And that is remarkable. It has the property that there is no turning back. Yes. It is so that since 13.82 billion years a time arrow exists in this universe. And it always goes forward. There is no way back.

Inflationary Cosmology This theory posits that the “big bang“ is kickstarted by a drop in potential energy filling reality itself. This potential energy is dubbed a “Hypothetical Inflaton Field”. Binary Universe In this universe, there is a constant amount of universe being created out of nothing, it may seem like it is violating the second law, however, it is not, and here’s why. The parallel universe theory is real and has now been proved with a series of physical experiments. The parallel universe theory is formally known as the Everett/Wheeler hypothesis or “the many worlds” interpretation of quantum mechanics. As a researcher with more than 20 years looking into the theory and its implications, I’ve done more than anyone to look for evidence that it is in fact true, as well as how it applies to fundamental questions in the advanced concept area, such as time travel. Last year, I began to formalize an approach to test my theory that retrocausality experiments and the Everett/Wheeler hypothesis are in fact related and could be brought under the umbrella of the Participatory Universe model, posited by John Archibald Wheeler, the same ‘Wheeler’ in the Everett/Wheeler hypothesis name. Because there is plenty detail in both the press release that I’ve provided a link to, as well as in the video reel which includes analysis of the experiments themselves, I will just say that my thinking was to mimic the typical retrocausality, ‘which way path’ test where the path of a photon has been altered after it has already passed that point, and as a result, it appears at a different detector than it should have - as if the change had altered its route in the past and produced an inconsistent result. This has been seen as a violation of causality, i.e. a time paradox, but I know that such paradoxes actually violate the Copenhagen interpretation which states in part that there can only be one outcome per universe. In short, looking at these experiments at the point of the path change, I saw the obvious - that this is where the universe splits - not with the past being changed, but a new parallel universe coming into being that has the new, inconsistent result - the photon at a detector which was not the one for the path that it had originally started down. Unlike the EWH, this is not directly the result of the decoherence of universes from a superpositional state, this is the result of the participatory universe model, where the universe (or omniverse, but NOT multiverse) responds to what has happened, and serves as the engine or functional operating system, for all of these kinds of quantum weirdness. As a result, evidence for parallel universes has been around for decades, but was simply being misinterpreted. My experiment proves this by performing the ‘which way path’ test with a laser pointer, a 2 way mirror as a beam splitter, and a high speed electric fan as a shutter system, to change the path of the transmission pulses that pass through the beam splitter while the reflective pulses strike a side wall. When a fan blade passes close enough behind a transmission laser pulse, the ‘which way path’ effect takes place and a laser hit is seen to have hit the side wall where only reflected pulses should have been. The proof that these hits are not reflected pulses is that these hits happen when there is no laser source to account for them. That is correct. The pulse has hit the side wall with no source, just as would be expected for a photon to suddenly hit a detector not in its orginal path, during the ‘which way path’ tests. These hits are actually the laser pulses arriving from the original universe, which decohered at the moment of the ‘which way path event’, into the new one which now has a new past - one where the laser did hit the side wall. The implications for all of this are explained in the press release above, which has a link to the paper I wrote, as well as the video reel. However, from this moment on, parallel universes stemming from quantum mechanics can no longer be viewed as simply science fiction. It’s the way reality works, and now those who thought otherwise will just have to deal with it…

The universe we live in may not be the only one out there. In fact, our universe could be just one of an infinite number of universes making up a "multiverse." Though the concept may stretch creduLity . there is good physics behind it. And there's not just one way to get to a multiverse — numerous physics theories independently point to such a conclusion. In fact, some experts think the existence of hidden universes is more likely than not. Here are the five most plausible scientific theories suggesting we live in a multiverse: 1. Infinite Universes Scientists can't be sure what the shape of space-time is, but most likely, it's flat (as opposed to spherical or even donut-shape) and stretches out infinitely. But if space-time goes on forever, then it must start repeating at some point, because there are a finite number of ways particles can be arranged in space and time. So if you look far enough, you would encounter another version of you — in fact, infinite versions of you. Some of these twins will be doing exactly what you're doing right now, while others will have worn a different sweater this morning, and still others will have made vastly different career and life choices. Because the observable universe extends only as far as light has had a chance to get in the 13.7 billion years since the Big Bang (that would be 13.7 billion light-years), the space-time beyond that distance can be considered to be its own separate universe. In this way, a multitude of universes exists next to each other in a giant patchwork quilt of universes. [Visualizations of Infinity: A Gallery]   ​​HiSpace-time may stretch out to infinity. If so, then everything in our universe is bound to repeat at some point, creating a patchwork quilt of infinite universe 2. Bubble Universes In addition to the multiple universes created by infinitely extending space-time, other universes could arise from a theory called "eternal inflation." Inflation is the notion that the universe expanded rapidly after the Big Bang, in effect inflating like a balloon. Eternal inflation, first proposed by Tufts University cosmologist Alexander Vilenkin, suggests that some pockets of space stop inflating, while other regions continue to inflate, thus giving rise to many isolated "bubble universes." Thus, our own universe, where inflation has ended, allowing stars and galaxies to form, is but a small bubble in a vast sea of space, some of which is still inflating, that contains many other bubbles like ours. And in some of these bubble universes, the laws of physics and fundamental constants might be different than in ours, making some universes strange places indeed.  ​​ 3. Parallel Universes Another idea that arises from string theory is the notion of "braneworlds" — parallel universes that hover just out of reach of our own, proposed by Princeton University's Paul Steinhardt and Neil Turok of the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in Ontario, Canada. The idea comes from the possibility of many more dimensions to our world than the three of space and one of time that we know. In addition to our own three-dimensional "brane" of space, other three-dimensional branes may float in a higher-dimensional space. ​Out universe may live on one membrane, or "brane" that is parallel to many others containing their own universes, all floating in a higher-dimensional space.  ​ 4. Daughter Universes The theory of quantum mechanics, which reigns over the tiny world of subatomic particles, suggests another way multiple universes might arise. Quantum mechanics describes the world in terms of probabilities, rather than definite outcomes. And the mathematics of this theory might suggest that all possible outcomes of a situation do occur — in their own separate universes. For example, if you reach a crossroads where you can go right or left, the present universe gives rise to two daughter universes: one in which you go right, and one in which you go left.   ​ 5. Mathematical Universes Scientists have debated whether mathematics is simply a useful tool for describing the universe, or whether math itself is the fundamental reality, and our observations of the universe are just imperfect perceptions of its true mathematical nature. If the latter is the case, then perhaps the particular mathematical structure that makes up our universe isn't the only option, and in fact all possible mathematical structures exist as their own separate universes.  ​

There is no one theory, there are many. They are real, in the sense that the theories exist. Are parallel universes real? That isn't really the important question in science and never has been. You cannot prove that Quora exists, you can prove nothing beyond the existence of your own mind and all that you can prove by logic alone (a small subset of mathematics). Everything else consists of assumptions, presumptions and observations that are (by definition) inaccurate. If you allow that senses you can't prove are telling you anything at all (see James Burke's The Real Thing for just how wrong your senses are) are nonetheless good enough to carry out scientific enquiry (which is obviously the case) then you have to dispense with notions of "real" and "proof". You are reduced instead to the Scientific Method. The Scientific Method denies that objective reality matters. What does matter, then? First, theories must be as simple as possible to explain the observations, neither being too simple to explain what is observed, nor multiplying entities unnecessarily. Second, theories must be predictive. Correlations don't matter, for they say nothing about whether something is a cause or an effect. Everything described may be an effect, with nothing described being a cause of any of the other phenomena. Everything may be coincidental (broken clocks aren't actually right twice a day, they are merely the same as the correct value). The only way to actually know is to make predictions about what will happen if certain things are true. But you can't be a passive observer, because that still doesn't tell you what's a free variable and what direction the relationship is in. I could predict that the stars come out on a clear night. It would be bogus, but passive observation would deceive you into thinking it was true. Active observation (by flying high enough, for example) would reveal that you can see stars at any time of day. Third, some non-empty set of predictions that can be made must be able to prove the theory false (not true, false). It is not required that every prediction be of this type, it is only necessary that there be at least one at any time. Many Worlds theory is a simple model that explains why quantum effects do not produce every possible outcome. Remember, you cannot have an effect without a cause and there is no cause that can collapse the probability wave. You are thus expressly forbidden from having any probability wave collapse just because. As long as you theorize that quantum particles exist, you have to explain why one and only one outcome is ever actually seen. However, it's not a theory until it makes a prediction. Whether it's testable at the time is unimportant, what matters is that a prediction is made. Since at least one prediction must be capable of proving the theory false, we might as well make this the prediction of interest. We know that the predicted behaviour of a particle, such an electron, is that of a particle and a wave, depending on the situation. Obviously, the laws of physics can't change according to the whim of some observer. If they could, you could cause an old-fashioned television to explode by deciding that electrons should be waves, or cause a modern computer to crash by deciding that electrons must be particles. So clearly, it should be obvious that both behaviours coexist. We are forbidden from explanations that are unduly complex or which fail to explain everything observed (time diffraction, spacial diffraction, electron tunnelling, quantum states, multiple simultaneous states in qbits). Partial explanations are too simple and, under Einstein's rules, too simple is inadequate. Since all of the non-particle behaviours occur over a very short interval of time, but does not occur over a longer time (so the probability waves collapse), you need to say where these entities now are. Conservation of Information forbids information being destroyed. Conservation of matter/energy forbids the structures just vanishing. We still need a prediction. One prediction is that everything is conserved, just conserved somewhere else, the Many Worlds theory. That meets most of our requirements, there really aren't any other theories that fit observations and don't violate conservation in some way. If a probability wave just vanishes then you've altered the total amount of information in the universe. Ok, now we need a prediction that we can falsify. We don't have to have performed the experiment, or know how to, we just have to know it can be done. Well, if we entangle two particles and subject one to an event where the probability wave will appear to collapse in one of two ways, the other end (since it must exist in the opposite state and only two states exist for it to be in) is in an interesting situation. Let's place them in different time frames, perfectly valid thing to do, every object exists in a freely-moving independent frame of reference. That's why two observers can't see things simultaneously, there's no such concept. But if the particles exist in different frames of reference and one particle exists in multiple states simultaneously, the second particle must exist not as a particle but as a wave, also existing in multiple states simultaneously even though it cannot do so as an instantaneous particle. So we now have a falsifiable prediction. If Many Worlds is true, then by linking one particle at the observer's end to the many particles in the different worlds, you force the first particle to behave as a wave. If it does not, if it exists in only one state (and if that state is shown to be what you would expect by observing the other particle) then particle/wave duality is NOT a product of the predicted window of time in which the Many Worlds overlap. We now have a means to falsify, a predictive model, and compliance with the requirements of a good model. That makes Many Worlds valid in science even if it's complete nonsense. Superstrings and Supergravity (a different sort of parallel universe model) also meet these criteria. Superstrings have non-zero (probably negative) gravity, so if you fail to detect regions of quantum foam that have strange variations in density that are not attributable to the randomness of the foam in areas where superstrings should reside, you can say you've falsified superstrings. Superstrings and supergravity model forces in a way that permit them to be unified in a single description, despite gravity being absurdly weak. Supergravity tells you what should happen if you expose gravitons. So we've predictions and falsifiability. Simplicity - that's where you get the real arguments, falsifiability debates are easily falsified. Foam multiverses, it's predicted by the Big Rip and is rather essential to a lot of the underpinnings of quantum mechanics. Falsify quantum mechanics, any of it, and you falsify foam multiverse theory. Because the foam multiverse is a prediction based on an existing model, it is the existing model that matters.

Depends on what you mean by “parallel universes”.If you are talking about an infinite universe having “other Earths” etc then yet I concede that if the universe is infinite in extent the cosmological principals hold then there are other “Earths” out there. This is just a consequence of an infinite universe and only so many configurations that our visible universe can have. The issue is that these other “Earths” are probably all causally disconnected from use, though in some portion of the universe there would be causally connected “Earths”. If you are talking about multiple universes like in either some brane cosmology or eternal inflation then again my answer is “Yes”. But in this multiverse the vast majority of “parallel universes” would be, as long as there isn’t something constraining them” vastly different then ours. And this time they are all causally disconnected from us. If you are talking about the “Many-Worlds” hypothesis that people often say every time you make a decision the universe is branched off then no. It, to me, implies some initial causal link but presents no mechanism for these “new” universes to be created and partitioned from the old universe. It is little more than a sci-fi plot. But let me entertain the situation for a minute. If the universe did split every time some wave function collapsed then since the big bang there would be orders of magnitude more “parallel” universes that have no Earth then ones that do have Earths. Unlike the infinite universe hypothesis there are a limited amount, tho staggering large, number of “decisions” that have been made since the big bang. We are talking about 6x10^59 Planck time since the big bang multiplied by the number of possible wave function collapses in a Hubble volume at any given instant. Most of which occurred before the Earth was even created at this point so the “Earth” wouldn’t even be around even if you could travel to one of these “parallel” universes you would most likely not be in one that contains an “Earth”. I see it as nothing more than a way to convey a concept withing QM.

Lots of things start off hypothetical and later are considered to really exist. Everything is possible in cosmology. Physicists and cosmologists are well used to considering all kinds of things which sound outlandish including; parallel universes; multiple universes; 10 or 11 dimensions rather than the 4 we are used to; and much more. In science none of these models have been proven, however science is evolving all the time. A couple of hundred years ago the idea that matter is actually composed entirely of empty space would have seemed like science fiction. Parallel universes are certainly possible and it is not impossible that we could get to the point where we have a widely accepted theory of such. There is one area of physics here where the notion of a SINGLE parallel universe has become “commonplace”. This is in the study of black holes.  It turns out that it is impossible to study what happens beyond the event horizon of a black hole without using what is called a coordinate transformation. This is called the Maximally Extended Schwarzschild Solution. What the problem is, is that from our place within the universe, any collapse of the black hole beyond the event horizon literally never happens because of gravitational time dilation. (It also means that the future singularity in the black hole must be after the last event in the universe, but I digress.) Nevertheless from General Relativity we know that in the local time frame of the collapsing matter traversing of the event horizon does take place. In order to look at this further it is accepted that the coordinate system must change in order to take into account (i) this universe (ii) the future singularity (within the black hole) (iii) a parallel universe and (iv) the past singularity (Big Bang/white hole)  Well, there you have it, science hypothesises a Parallel Universe! Why this is a required feature of the Maximally Extended Schwarzschild Solution I don’t know. I do know that there is a lot of confusion in science at this time where black holes are being considered. Even the best minds on the planet, like Stephen Hawking, Sean Carroll and Leonard Susskind, are not even close to agreeing what an event horizon actually is. I do know that Sean Carroll for one is investigating a role for an anti- or parallel universe in modelling the expansion of the Big Bang/white hole. So there is at least a chance that a parallel universe is real and not just a hypothesis.

There is no scientific proof of that but many still believe that multi-universes exist. I have read various articles on ”proof of parallel universes” and I am gonna share some of them with you here. Man from an unknown country On July 1954, a man arrived at Tokyo airport. On checking his passport they found out that he hails from a country called Taured. Now, the passport looked genuine except for the fact that there is no such country as Taured. Also, the currency bills he was carrying were from an unknown bank, the company he claimed to work for had no knowledge of him and the hotel he claimed to have a reservation for had never heard of him either. The man mysteriously vanished the very next day. Ghost city of China People of China were mesmerised when they saw a towering city of sky scrapers appeared from the clouds. It is believed that a parallel universe opened up for a brief amount of time. Obviously, other theories also exist like the phenomenon being called as a mirage or a secret weapon to create holographic images etc Story of Lerina García Many physicists believe that it is possible for us to make a quantum jump sometimes (unknowingly). When this happens, we shift from our current universe to some other universe. The same happened with Lerina García when she woke up one day in a world — our world — that did not belong to her. Below is a part taken from her interview: “So I went to work in my car, which was parked where I’d always parked, and it was the same office I’d worked in for the last 20 years. But when I got to my department, it wasn’t my department. It has names on the door and mine wasn’t on it. I thought I was on the wrong floor, but no, it was my own floor. I went over to the office’s wireless section and looked myself up. I still worked there, but in another department, reporting to a superior I didn’t even know.” All these incidents don't give a concrete evidence of the existence of parallel universes but they surely make us wonder that whether there is another universe where the world is at peace, children don’t die of hunger and students don’t commit suicides.

response.answer_text: We will never really know. Just like extra dimensions, it's something which we can not perceive.  Imagine living in a 2D world. You know only about forwards, backwards and sideways. Up and down is terms you can not understand, and someone can not explain it to you since they can not compare it to anything you know or that you can observe, since everything is in 2D. So if a 3D ball was to float above this 2D world, it would see the 2D word, but the 3D world would not see it, since they do not know about up and down. If this ball was to move downwards, through the 2D world, they would only see a small dot appear, which would then become wider and wider (since the ball becomes wider towards it's center), and then thinner and thinner again until it just disappears. They can only see on the X axis, and not the Y axis.  So will not be able to see a 4D object, since our minds can only understand 3 dimensional objects. So even if it is right in front of us, we might not even see it. But just like the 2D people might have seen a thin line appearing, which just disappears...we might catch glimpses of things appearing and then just disappearing which could point to another dimension existing with things in it. But other than suspecting it, we would not be able to go there, since our minds can not understand it, and we can not see it, even though it could be all around us at this very moment. The same goes for parallel universes. They could be all around us, but since we live in this one, we can not be aware of the other.  When talking about time travelling, then the need for parallel universes becomes more obvious, especially when thinking about the grandmother paradox, where you travel back in time to kill your grandmother. If you kill her, your mother did not get born, and thus, neither did you. If you did not get born, how could you have travelled back in time to kill her in the first place? Thus, if you then add in the possibility of parrallel universes, suddenly time travelling into the past could work, since you you could then time travel, but in essence when you do, you travel to another universe, in which you can kill your grandmother without causing any repercussions in the universe you came from. Thus, you only kill your grandmother in THAT universe, and not the one you came from.

In my opinion, it does not even qualify as a theory. First, for all I know there could be a parallel universe, but since we cannot ever detect anything from it, then what we see is no different from when it does not exist. There is also the “many worlds” interpretation of quantum mechanics, which argues that the wave function does not collapse, but merely splinters and all possibilities occur in some universe, which seems to imply an infinity of universes. My view is this is just a “get out of jail” card for the inability to deal with the implications of wave function probabilities. In my opinion, a theory has to do several things. The first is it must account, or potentially account for what we know that is relevant. There should also be, in the known data set, some issues that standard theory has trouble with. Standard theory might “explain” them eventually, but perhaps with a huge number of terms, or terms that you feel do not really make sense, or involve mathematics without a plausible mechanism. The theory of Claudius Ptolemy fitted that - it calculated everything you wanted, but it really did not have a physical basis. So the new theory should fix those issues, and preferably simplify things, and also not involve too many propositions that involve holding your breath. You do not have to get rid of those entirely - Newton’s heliocentric dynamics required gravity to act at a distance and newton did not know why. Quantum electrodynamics requires a rather dubious renormalisation issue. You can swallow some, in the hope that things will eventually be solved properly, but there should be a limit. The next thing is the theory should solve some problem that standard theory does not solve, and it should make some sort of prediction about something. Then it should be in a form that someone else can say, if this is true, then I should see . . . That means there should be a way to test it, and falsify it. The problem with parallel universes is they do not interact with ours, so there is no possible test, the theory explains nothing, because the outputs of what it accounts for is the empty set.

Many mathematical models repeatedly generate solutions that strongly hint at and in many cases require there to be multiple parallel universes. Without going through all the various explanations in too much depth, there appear to be at least 4 levels of parallel universes which range from possible to likely: Universes beyond our observable Universe. The known Universe (i.e., the part that we can see) is a spherical volume of space-time approximately 93 billion light-years in diameter. Measurements taken of the curvature of space suggest that space-time is very flat. Which suggests that it may well go on forever. In which case the Universe that we can see is but one very very very tiny part of a space which may contain an infinity of Universes that we will never be able to see. In my personal opinion, this scenario is not only likely but very probable.Quantum Universes: Research in quantum physics has proved that subatomic particles can exist in more than one location at the same time. In fact, these subatomic particles do not appear to be made up of anything solid at all. They are merely ‘clouds’ of energy. It is impossible to measure their speed and position at the same time. When you try, all kinds of weird things happen. It appears that each particle has no specific position in space until it is measured. This and other facts, has led science to the conclusion that our quantum Universe is just one of perhaps an infinite number of parallel quantum universes that co-exist together, each with a slightly different history than the other. In my personal opinion, this scenario is also very probable.Higher Dimensional Universes. There is some evidence that our Universe exists in a higher dimensional space (known as the true vacuum) where universes pop into existence all the time, like tiny bubbles in an infinite ocean. They spread out in all directions as they pop out of the nothingness as the space in which they are embedded rapidly expands. Some scientists claim they have found evidence in the distribution of galaxy clusters in our Universe that one or more of these outside universes may have collided, or more accurately, bumped up against, our own. In my personal opinion, this scenario is also very probable.Virtual Universes. There is an argument in science that since we already have the technology to create virtual universes in our computers, then there must exist far more virtual universes than real ones. Since the number of virtual universes is so staggeringly large, so the argument goes, the chances of our living in a real universe are remote. Leading to the conclusion that this Universe and we who occupy it, are simply computer programs operating inside someone else’s machine. The detailed argument is often supported with intricate facts figures and statistics, but this is the gist of it. In my personal opinion, this scenario is rather improbable. Why? Because there is some evidence (however flimsy) for scenarios 1 to 3, but only highly dubious assumptions for scenario 4.In effect, we appear to live in an infinity of universes that span multiple dimensions of space-time that we cannot see. If this is the case then our universe is but one tiny speck in an infinite arena of universes that stretches away forever in an endless cosmic firmament. If you’d like to read about the multiverse from the number one expert in the field, take a look at the website of Professor Max Tegmark, who, to the best of my knowledge, is the world authority on parallel universes. The Universes of Max Tegmark

Absolutely so! Not only the possibility of a Parallel Universe that does exist,but many of them in fact,which collectively can also be described of course as the Multiverse. There is two sides to the issue of the scientific question of whether there is a Multiverse---those being believers and nonbelievers,both of which are strongly committed to their convictions.So rather than to just be yet another vote in favor of the existence of a Multiverse,here for you is an article that may perhaps be the most compelling case for it so far.There is no indisputable evidence to support the existence of a Multiverse yet,but the following excerpt shows promise in the pursuit of the truth to the big question: [Excerpt] Scientists Discover Possible First Proof of Parallel Universes May 18, 2017 by PAUL RATNER  Tarantula nebula. Credit: Pixabay. A new study about one of the most inexplicable places in the cosmos may offer the first proof that we are living in a multiverse. The idea of a “multiverse” proposes that an infinite amount of universes, including the one we are living in, exist in parallel to each other. These universes differ in a variety of physical properties, featuring multiple Big Bangs, space bubbles and maybe even an alternate version of you who is reading this article in a world run by slugs. The “multiverse” hypothesis has been so far been impossible to test but has supporters among such scientists as Stephen Hawking, Michio Kaku, Neil deGrasse Tyson and Leonard Susskind. The study by British astronomers focuses on what’s known as the “Cold Spot” - an especially cold area of space that has been observed in the microwave background radiation coming from the early Universe 13 billion years ago. Usually temperatures of the radiation vary throughout the universe, but this area of coolness is much larger than others (about 0.00015 degrees Celsius colder than its surroundings).  The map of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) sky produced by the Planck satellite. Red represents slightly warmer regions, and blue slightly cooler regions. Credit: ESA and Durham University. The Cold Spot, first found by NASA in 2004, is a strange place 1.8 billion light years across that doesn’t comfortably gel with existing cosmological models. One explanation is that it simply doesn’t exist, being just an illusion created by the expansion of the universe. Spaces with lower amount of galaxies or “voids” form as the expansion accelerates. With 10,000 fewer galaxies, the Cold Spot would be a “supervoid”. But the study, published in UK’s Royal Astronomical Society, claims to prove that the supervoid is not a valid solution to the Cold Spot's mystery. The researchers think that instead of one giant emptiness in that area, there are galaxy clusters gathered around smaller bubble-like voids. And, significantly, these would be too small to be responsible for lowering the temperature in the Cold Spot. In fact, other answers must be sought. The scientists, led by postgraduate student Ruari Mackenzie and Professor Tom Shanks in Durham University's Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, think one possible hypothesis is that the Cold Spot resulted from a collision between our universe during its early days and another universe. The energy release of such an impact would have created the Cold Spot. "We can't entirely rule out that the Spot is caused by an unlikely fluctuation explained by the standard model. But if that isn't the answer, then there are more exotic explanations. Perhaps the most exciting of these is that the Cold Spot was caused by a collision between our universe and another bubble universe. If further, more detailed, analysis of CMB [Cosmic Microwave Background] data proves this to be the case then the Cold Spot might be taken as the first evidence for the multiverse – and billions of other universes may exist like our own,” said Professor Tom Shanks. The multiverse, while an exciting idea, has its detractors. Some physicists feel since it’s not something observable or provable, then a discussion of it is pointless or even unscientific. But when more ordinary solutions come up empty, the doors of science open wider. [End Excerpt]

Attention, this information is to be taken with tweezers, but it has the merit of being very interesting for understanding our universe as well as our cosmos. In a study published at the end of April, British researchers from the University of Durham questioned the possibility of the existence of parallel universes, in order to explain an "anomaly" in the cosmos. If the subject interests you, here is a TEDx conference on the subject. THE MULTIVERS OR THE FANTASY OF SCIENTISTS To get this article off to a good start, let's take the time to lay the groundwork for parallel universes. If you are a fan of science fiction, the concept must obviously speak to you. What is a multiverse? Broadly speaking, we define this term as the possible existence of other universes having its own physical laws and its own reality. For example, if Chuck Norris is a star of the martial arts and the internet, in another universe, he could be the President of the United States. This idea is taken into account in the theory of multiple parallel universes. An American mathematician and physicist, Hugh Everett, had put forward this hypothesis in the context of quantum physics, with the aim of proposing an interpretation of the mechanism of waves. The expression "multiverse" was then theorized, and popularized a little more "simply". For fans of the genre, the saga A la Croisée des Mondes by Philipp Pulmann evokes this principle in a sentence that has remained famous. A character evokes this idea, having for knowledge the works carried out by Everett. Because this world, like all the other universes, was born from the result of probabilities. Take the example of heads or tails: the coin you throw may fall on heads or tails, but we don't know in advance which side it will fall on. If it's on the face, it means that the possibility that it fell on the pile has failed. But just before we launch it, both probabilities have the same chance. If, in another world, the coin falls on the pile at that time, the two worlds separate. I'm using the example of a coin to make it clearer. In reality, these probability failures occur at the level of elementary particles.

As per Wikipedia A parallel universe is a hypothetical self-contained reality co-existing with one's own. A specific group of parallel universes are called a "multiverse", although this term can also be used to describe the possible parallel universes that constitute reality. So it may or may not be possible.  This concept was also found in ancient Hindu mythology, in texts such as the Puranas, which expressed an infinite number of universes, each with its own gods.Similarly in Persian literature, "The Adventures of Bulukiya", a tale in the One Thousand and One Nights, describes the protagonist Bulukiya learning of alternative worlds/universes that are similar to but still distinct from his own. In popular culture like in DC's Flash Traveling from one universe to other is possible through breaches.A breach, also called a portal or wormhole, is a hole or rift in the dimensional barrier, bridging any location to another.Breach act like "door," with a "hallway" in between that's always shifting and twisting, and if you stabilize the door, you stabilize the hallway. Experienced speedsters can travel through breaches if they're fast enough. The "God of Speed" Savitar is even able to utilize them so well that he can hop in and out of a location. Around 2010, scientists such as Stephen M. Feeney analyzed Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP) data and claimed to find evidence suggesting that our universe collided with other (parallel) universes in the distant past. However, a more thorough analysis of data from the WMAP and from the Planck satellite, which has a resolution 3 times higher than WMAP, did not reveal any statistically significant evidence of such a bubble universe collision. In addition, there was no evidence of any gravitational pull of other universes on ours. But this in no way means that there isn’t more Universe out there beyond the portion that’s accessible to us. In fact, from both observational and theoretical points-of-view, we have every reason to believe there’s plenty more, and perhaps even infinitely more. Observationally, we can measure a few different interesting quantities, including the spatial curvature of the Universe, how smooth and uniform it is in both temperature and density, and how it’s evolved over time. Even if it was possible for us to travel to parallel universe it would have taken billions of years to reach there. So what does this mean for you? It means it’s up to you to make this Universe count. Make the choices that leave you with no regrets: take the dream job, stand up for yourself, navigate through the pitfalls as best you can, and go all-out every day of your life. There is no other Universe that has this version of you in it, and there is no future for you other than the one you live yourself into. Make it the best one possible.

response.answer_text: Perhaps. That’s probably the most honest answer one may give. The notion of parallel universes is but one consideration of a multiverse. Max Tegmark has devised a categorization consisting of four ‘levels’ of multiverses, each based on different scientific ideas but each being increasingly speculative. I will explain the underlying theories below: Metric expansion of space — The universe went through a period of exponential expansion from 10−36−36 to 10−32−32 seconds after the Big Bang, called the inflationary period. After this period the universe continued to expand, but at a less rapid rate. However, it’s accelerating in its expansion and will continue to do so. As the universe keeps expanding, the observable universe will keep getting smaller as more objects go beyond the so-called Hubble sphere. This is the sphere of observation—beyond which galaxies recede from the observer faster than light—for a given observer in the universe. As the observable universe is estimated to be 93 billion light-years in diameter, observers who are more than 46.5 billion light-years beyond this diameter will never be able to get any information from our observable universe, nor we from them. For all intents and purposes those island Hubble spheres are separate universes. This is a level 1 multiverse.Eternal inflation — Inflation could be going on forever. With different inflationary regions, some regions expand faster than others, and so you get distinct regions of space. As such, so-called pocket universes emerge. This is a level 2 multiverse.Many-worlds interpretation — Everett’s many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics indicates that every quantum possibility inherent to the quantum wavefunction becomes a real possibility in some reality. As such, a construct of parallel universes emerges. This is a level 3 multiverse.Ultimate Ensemble — This theory posits that all computable mathematical structures must have a reality somewhere. This is a level 4 multiverse.Do these ideas make sense? Yes, but they are increasingly speculative. A level 1 multiverse is a given, but (eternal) inflation already comes with problems. I can highly recommend reading “The inflation debate — Is the theory at the heart of modern cosmology deeply flawed?” by Paul Steinhardt to learn more about inflation. As for a level 3 multiverse or a construct of parallel universes, their existence are assumed by some, but may never be validated. Each collapsed wavefunction splits the inherent possibilities and thus these worlds will by definition never be able to communicate. However, it may be that in each parallel universe, certain actions will hold true in a plurality of parallel universes, and so multiple parallel universes may visit the same moment/configuration. This is where one universe can assume to position of a parallel one—exceedingly unlikely as this may be. But the event would be but an experience of a moment, and not a plurality of moments in different universes. So you would still never know if an event was shared by multiple parallel universes.  See more Max Tegmark on the multiverseRead more The Universes of Max Tegmark

There are two approaches to answer your question, one mathematical and the other philosophical. Neither one is proof of reality or non-reality since theories do not prove anything, they can only be disproven. With that being said I will answer you question using Gordon’s Theory of Everything. Gordon’s Theory of Everything starts with two postulates added to the true void universe. We would need to define that the true void universe means that there are NO other parallel universes either. Gordon’s theory of everything shows how our universe is created. That would mean that our universe would have to be the first universe since its starting postulates are only for our universe. If parallel universes were co-created along with our universe, then they should be able to be derived from the primordial postulates of Gordon’s Theory of Everything. Gordon’s Theory of Everything could not derive the creation of other universes andn provides a very specific reason why parallel universes are not real. The primordial postulates of our universe include 1) The component building block of spacetime that exist in humongous numbers and 2) The incredible amount of energy required for their initial alignment. The component building block of spacetime is called a GOD Entity (Gordon Omnipresent Dot). Let’s say there was only one GOD entity in the universe and we wanted to add another GOD entity. The question to ask is… Would the first GOD entity interact with the additional GOD entity? If the answer is no, then each GOD entity would exist unto itself and represent a universe unto itself. If the answer is yes, then any more additional GOD entities would also interact with all other existing GOD entities and only one universe would be created. How do I know Gordon’s Theory of Everything’s prediction that there is only one universe is correct? Because everything that is possible and real must be able to be derived from the two postulates. If not, then whatever can’t be derived does not represent reality. Gordon’s Theory of Everything shows that it is not possible for a fundamental particle to exist as a magnetic monopole… Physicists should stop looking for a fundamental magnetic monopole particle AND parallel universes!

To extend the same idea to bigger scale, there might be other universes out there that play out different possibilities of what universes could be, in a hand-wavy sense, and not in the strict many-worlds interpretation sense where each slightly different outcome splits into another entire universe.

Possibly the most important ‘why’ question of all, and as such it should receive more attention. Some things are better reasoned through from first principles, and I think the universe is definitely one of those things. Here’s my view. We can fairly safely rephrase the question into “Why, and how, did the universe come to exist from nothing?” But how can we say it probably came from nothing? Well, the Big Bang played backwards suggests that it began as a dimensionless state. Also, the universe is spatially ‘flat’, which suggests that the positive energy of the universe balances the negative (gravity). In other words, the net energy sum of the universe is zero. In reference to this feature, physicist Alan Guth once said that the universe is “the ultimate free lunch”. Some have suggested that the universe may have come from a black hole, or a quantum fluctuation in a preexisting universe. Two problems here - the universe is almost inconceivably big (possibly infinite), so how could it have come from such a state. Also, if we posit some kind of preexisting universe (or black hole) then we come up against the question of where THAT came from, so the question of something from nothing never completely goes away. For something that is potentially infinite in extent, nothingness is an excellent candidate for a preexisting state. That is because nothingness, by its very nature, should have no limit or extent, or else it would be something rather than nothing. So if we ask “Why, and how, did the universe come to exist from nothing?”, we can apply a couple of other fairly logical caveats. Firstly, that there is nothing else to create the universe but itself (because it came from nothing). Secondly, that the universe EXISTS. Existence, as we know it in this universe, consists of a what, a where and a when. i.e. space, time and complexity. So the universe should be capable of making its own space, time and complexity. I would go so far as to say that these THREE elements should be considered fundamental dimensions but the complexity dimension isn't recognised because it isn't directly measurable, and probably requires some input from a universal consciousness. Both these features (but particularly the latter) cut against the grain of standard scientific reasoning. For more on this see Gavin Rowland's answer to Can we explain the fine-tuned universe without religion or parallel universes? But why would nothingness come into existence, rather than just staying as nothingness? This may be a special case of what is known in physics as symmetry breaking. Basically if something is symmetrical it is seen as being unstable, and prone to breaking symmetrically into something more ordered. As physicist Frank Wilczek has pointed out, nothing is more symmetrical than nothingness, so if symmetry breaking applies in this situation then nothingness would inevitably break into something. It is interesting that, while the universe appears to have created spatial separation and the forward movement of time, it has also created a force, namely gravity, which contracts things spatially and slows time towards a dimensionless point - the spacetime singularity. This is another way of looking at the “free lunch” idea and food for thought for those who seek some kind of mathematical union between gravity and the other forces of nature. Quantum gravity may ultimately be a fool’s errand because the universe created gravity out of symmetry breaking and conservation of energy considerations. And physics may be floundering for solutions because it isn't thinking simply and fundamentally enough.

Is it possible to live another life in a parallel universe or omniverse? When you experience a déjà vu, are you drawing this experience from a parallel universe?Let me explain something I apparently know about them. A parallel universe or alternative reality is a hypothetical self-contained separate reality coexisting with one’s own. A specific group of parallel universes is called a ‘multiverse’, although this term can also be used to describe the possible parallel universes that constitute reality. While the terms ‘parallel universe’ and ‘alternative reality’ are generally synonymous and can be used interchangeably in most cases, there is sometimes an additional connotation implied with the term ‘alternative reality’ that implies that the reality is a variant of our own. The term ‘parallel universe’ is more general, without any connotations implying a relationship, or lack of relationship, with our own universe. A universe where the very laws of nature are different – for example, one in which there are no relativistic limitations and the speed of light can be exceeded – would in general count as a parallel universe but not an alternative reality. The correct quantum mechanical definition of parallel universes is “universes that are separated from each other by a single quantum  The idea of a “multiverse” proposes that an infinite amount of universes, including the one. The idea of a “multiverse” proposes that an infinite amount of universes, including the one we are living in, exist in parallel to each other. These universes differ in a variety of physical properties, featuring multiple Big Bangs, space bubbles and maybe even an alternate version of you who is reading this article in a world run by slugs. The “multiverse” hypothesis has been so far been impossible to test but has supporters among such scientists as Stephen Hawking, Michio Kaku, Neil deGrasse Tyson and Leonard Susskind. The study by British astronomers focuses on what’s known as the “Cold Spot” - an especially cold area of space that has been observed in the microwave background radiation coming from the early Universe 13 billion years ago. Usually temperatures of the radiation vary throughout the universe, but this area of coolness is much larger than others (about 0.00015 degrees Celsius colder than its surroundings).  The map of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) sky produced by the Planck satellite. Red represents slightly warmer regions, and blue slightly cooler regions. Credit: ESA and Durham University. The Cold Spot, first found by NASA in 2004, is a strange place 1.8 billion light years across that doesn’t comfortably gel with existing cosmological models. One explanation is that it simply doesn’t exist, being just an illusion created by the expansion of the universe. Spaces with lower amount of galaxies or “voids” form as the expansion accelerates. With 10,000 fewer galaxies, the Cold Spot would be a “supervoid”. But the study, published in UK’s Royal Astronomical Society, claims to prove that the supervoid is not a valid solution to the Cold Spot's mystery. The researchers think that instead of one giant emptiness in that area, there are galaxy clusters gathered around smaller bubble-like voids. And, significantly, these would be too small to be responsible for lowering the temperature in the Cold Spot. In fact, other answers must be sought. The scientists, led by postgraduate student Ruari Mackenzie and Professor Tom Shanks in Durham University's Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, think one possible hypothesis is that the Cold Spot resulted from a collision between our universe during its early days and another universe. The energy release of such an impact would have created the Cold Spot. We can't entirely rule out that the Spot is caused by an unlikely fluctuation explained by the standard model. But if that isn't the answer, then there are more exotic explanations. Perhaps the most exciting of these is that the Cold Spot was caused by a collision between our universe and another bubble universe. If further, more detailed, analysis of CMB [Cosmic Microwave Background] data proves this to be the case then the Cold Spot might be taken as the first evidence for the multiverse – and billions of other universes may exist like our own, The multiverse, while an exciting idea, has its detractors. Some physicists feel since it’s not something observable or provable, then a discussion of it is pointless or even unscientific. But when more ordinary solutions come up empty, the doors of science open wider. Thank you for reading.

We don't know what the shape of space-time is exactly. One prominent theory is that it is flat and goes on forever. This would present the possibility of many universes being out there. But with that topic in mind, it's possible that universes can start repeating themselves. That's because particles can only be put together in so many ways. More about that in a moment. 2. Another theory for multiple universes comes from "eternal inflation." Based on research from Tufts University cosmologist Alexander Vilenkin, when looking at space-time as a whole, some areas of space stop inflating like the Big Bang inflated our own universe. Others, however, will keep getting larger. So if we picture our own universe as a bubble, it is sitting in a network of bubble universes of space. What's interesting about this theory is the other universes could have very different laws of physics than our own, since they are not linked. 3. Or perhaps multiple universes can follow the theory of quantum mechanics (how subatomic particles behave), as part of the "daughter universe" theory. If you follow the laws of probability, it suggests that for every outcome that could come from one of your decisions, there would be a range of universes — each of which saw one outcome come to be. So in one universe, you took that job to China. In another, perhaps you were on your way and your plane landed somewhere different, and you decided to stay. And so on. 4. Another possible avenue is exploring mathematical universes, which, simply put, explain that the structure of mathematics may change depending in which universe you reside. "A mathematical structure is something that you can describe in a way that's completely independent of human baggage," said theory-proposer Max Tegmark of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as quoted in the 2012 article. "I really believe that there is this universe out there that can exist independently of me that would continue to exist even if there were no humans." 5. And last but not least as the idea of parallel universes. To go back to the idea that space-time is flat, the number of possible particle configurations in multiple universes would be limited to 10^10^122 distinct possibilities, to be exact. So, with an infinite number of cosmic patches, the particle arrangements within them must repeat — infinitely many times over. This means there are infinitely many "parallel universes": cosmic patches exactly the same as ours (containing someone exactly like you), as well as patches that differ by just one particle's position, patches that differ by two particles' positions, and so on down to patches that are totally different from ours. Arguing against a parallel universe Not everyone agrees with the parallel universe theory, however. A 2015 article on Medium by astrophysicist Ethan Siegal agreed that space-time could go on forever in theory, but said that there are some limitations with that idea. The key problem is the universe is just under 14 billion years old. So our universe's age itself is obviously not infinite, but a finite amount. This would (simply put) limit the number of possibilities for particles to rearrange themselves, and sadly make it less possible that your alternate self did get on that plane after all to see China. Also, the expansion at the beginning of the universe took place exponentially because there was so much "energy inherent to space itself," he said. But over time, that inflation obviously slowed — those particles of matter created at the Big Bang are not continuing to expand, he pointed out. Among his conclusions: that means that multiverses would have different rates of inflation and different times (longer or shorter) for inflation. This decreases the possibilities of universes similar to our own. "Even setting aside issues that there may be an infinite number of possible values for fundamental constants, particles and interactions, and even setting aside interpretation issues such as whether the many-worlds-interpretation actually describes our physical reality," Siegal said, "the fact of the matter is that the number of possible outcomes rises so quickly — so much faster than merely exponentially — that unless inflation has been occurring for a truly infinite amount of time, there are no parallel universes identical to this one." But rather than seeing this lack of other universes as a limitation, Siegal instead takes the philosophy that it shows how important it is to celebrate being unique. He advises to make the choices that work for you, which "leave you with no regrets." That's because there are no other realities where the choices of your dream self play out; you, therefore, are the only person that can make those choices happen.

In 1962, Hugh Everett presented his idea of the relative state formulation, also referred to as a theory of parallel universes. In Quantum Mechanics, the outcome of any given event is not certain but can be described by a set of probabilities, one for each possible outcome. Everett’s thesis is that each outcome must occur, each in a different universe. It implies that there is then an infinity of universes. This theory is not falsifiable, that is there is no way to test the theory. As such it’s not really part of science but is what we might call a conjecture, perhaps a part of Metaphysics. In recent times the theory has become popular among some prominent theoretical cosmologists. It is sometimes combined with the idea of a multiverse. This plethora of universes suggests an explanation of the constants of nature that are fundamental to the existence of our world. Had any of these constants been off by a small amount, our world could not exist. But if there is an infinity of universes, then we appear in the only one that can support our existence, simply because it would not be possible for our world to evolve anywhere else—this is the so-called anthropomorphic theory of our universe. So, is it real? We’ll never know. Unless someone comes up with a way of detecting other universes.

Yes quite possibly. Observations of the cosmic microwave background are consistent with inflation. And many of those models have eternal inflation. Eternal inflation results in a myriad of pocket universes as they drop out of the larger inflation process. Andrei Linde is one of the fathers of inflationary Big Bang theory, and the originator of the chaotic inflation models. Chaotic inflation, and another leading model, ‘new’ inflation, both appear to result in eternal inflation; this gives rise to the multiverse scenario. That is, inflation keeps going in most of space, while multiple universes form and separate from the inflation process. That separation out is the Big Bang for a particular universe; at the end of its inflation era it dumps its energy into particles and radiation and a much slower expansion ensues. Here’s my blog on this and it has a link to a Linde review article: Search Results for “Multiverse ” – Dark Matter, Dark Energy, Dark Gravity

The current mainstream idea of multiple universes comes from String Theory, whose very powerful mathematics allows for multiple universes.  The idea seems to have gotten a push from people like Leonard Suskind of Stanford University as a response to the naive form of the anthropic principle, an answer in turn to "the fine tuning problem."  There are a dozen or two parameters in the formulas that describe the universe that have extraordinarily precise values and if any one of them were off by the smallest little bit, the universe could not be the way it is and there would be no life in it.  The naive anthropic principle simply states:  The parameters are what they are or we wouldn't be around to wonder about them. Suskind, in his book, "The Cosmic Landscape" develops the idea that String Theory describes a reality in which there are 10^500 universes, all with randomly different fine tuning values.  At least one of them would then have to have the values that we observe -- ours. Skeptics point out that String Theory is simply math and no novel part of it is remotely based on observation.  So while one can imagine other universes based on the mathematics of String Theory, no one, to my knowledge, has come up with any plausible way to test the multiple universe idea. But even with 10^500 possible universes, the idea of a truly parallel universe where we all exist in duplicate but follow a different historical trajectory seems intuitively very unlikely, particularly given that the history of our universe (and presumably the history of all other universes) is the result of "frozen quantum accidents", fundamentally random in nature and unpredictable (even in theory).

The parallel universe theory is basically scientists engaging in a pleasant form of science fiction. Sometimes they will pretend that they are discussing real science, but they aren’t. (In a similar manner, some magicians will claim they are doing true magic, rather than just tricks.) In science, a theory is not a valid theory unless it shows what kind of observation would falsify it. That was a criterion developed by the great theorist of science, Karl Popper. It was the standard that I was taught when I was a graduate student. I consider it to be the fundamental foundation of science, the criterion that separates science from non-science. The parallel universe “theory” doesn’t qualify. When I came up with my new theory of time (see my book Now: The Physics of Time) I considered it to be essential to devise an experiment that could falsify the theory, or confirm it—but it had to be able to do both! It was hard, but as I was finishing the book (actually, when the book was in proof!) LIGO discovered its incredible gravitational waves, and I immediately realized that such observations provided the key to testing my theory. I made some additions in the proof that show how to falsify my theory.

There are at least five theories why a multiverse is possible - 1. We don't know what the shape of space-time is exactly. One prominent theory is that it is flat and goes on forever. This would present the possibility of many universes being out there. But with that topic in mind, it's possible that universes can start repeating themselves. That's because particles can only be put together in so many ways. More about that in a moment. 2. Another theory for multiple universes comes from "eternal inflation." Based on research from Tufts University cosmologist Alexander Vilenkin, when looking at space-time as a whole, some areas of space stop inflating like the Big Bang inflated our own universe. Others, however, will keep getting larger. So if we picture our own universe as a bubble, it is sitting in a network of bubble universes of space. What's interesting about this theory is the other universes could have very different laws of physics than our own, since they are not linked. 3. Or perhaps multiple universes can follow the theory of quantum mechanics (how subatomic particles behave), as part of the "daughter universe" theory. If you follow the laws of probability, it suggests that for every outcome that could come from one of your decisions, there would be a range of universes — each of which saw one outcome come to be. So in one universe, you took that job to India. In another, perhaps you were on your way and your plane landed somewhere different (say Australia) , and you decided to stay. And so on. 4. Another possible avenue is exploring mathematical universes, which, simply put, explain that the structure of mathematics may change depending in which universe you reside. "A mathematical structure is something that you can describe in a way that's completely independent of human baggage," said theory-proposer Max Tegmark of the MIT. "I really believe that there is this universe out there that can exist independently of me that would continue to exist even if there were no humans." 5. And last but not least as the idea of parallel universes. To go back to the idea that space-time is flat, the number of possible particle configurations in multiple universes would be limited to 10^10^122 distinct possibilities, to be exact. So, with an infinite number of cosmic patches, the particle arrangements within them must repeat — infinitely many times over. This means there are infinitely many "parallel universes": cosmic patches exactly the same as ours (containing someone exactly like you), as well as patches that differ by just one particle's position, patches that differ by two particles' positions, and so on down to patches that are totally different from ours. Source - Space.com
