Do you believe in parallel universes? also state why. Quantum Space Theory gives a very clear description of a plausible multiverse, and actually converted me to the idea. So until contradictory information of more credibility comes my way, I believe in a multiverse, or in parallel universes. However, to explain why I’ll have to give a quick overview of the critical concepts. QST posits the existence of spacetime quanta one plank-length in diameter which resonate (or pulse) in plank-seconds. These are the smallest units of space and time that have any meaning, which is to say that trying to measure anything smaller goes beyond any definition of time or space that we can conceive of. Matter is made of this material, and in between each individual quanta which make up the fabric of spacetime are another four dimensions. Three superspatial dimensions that the quanta move around in, and one supertime dimension, which keeps track of the number of individual resonations (how many times each quanta has pulsed). Furthermore, QST posits that inside each quanta lies another set of quanta, giving the theoretical model three more spatial dimensions. Combined with our spactimes four, and the four of superspacetime (not the model’s term, but mine for the sake of expediency, which this aside most certainly defeats the purpose of), this gives us eleven dimensions. Now, on to why I believe in a multiverse. Please comment if you need any further information to understand, I love talking about Quantum Space Theory. Anyway, theoretically, inside each quanta there could be an entire universe. These tiny cosmi would be of the same structure and type as ours, because that is the way this kind of spacetime geometry would operate. That’s not all; if each quanta in our universe contains its own tiny cosmi, we could possibly be inside one tiny quanta from another unimaginably huge cosmos. If QST is correct, then given the infinitesimally small size of quanta, contained within your body would be enough cosmi that every single potential way the universe could go is present. The full entirety of the possibilities, from if the dinosaurs were still alive to if the Milky Way never existed, would just be happening all around us and inside us. According to QST, the cosmos is a perspective-less infinite fractal happening. Every single moment is resounding into forever alongside every other possible moment. The echoes of eternity crescendo unending. Poetry aside, it’s an amazing theory, and it’s concept of multiverse is one I fully comprehend and ascribe to. Einstein’s Intuition : Quantum Space Theory

For years, scientists have been baffled by a weird anomaly far away in space: a mysterious cold spot about 1.8 billion light-years across. It is cooler than its surroundings by around 0.00015 degrees Celsius (0.00027 degrees Fahrenheit), a fact astronomers discovered by measuring background radiation throughout the universe. Previously, astronomers believed that this space could be cooler simply because it had less matter in it than most sections of space. They dubbed it a massive supervoid and estimated that it had 10,000 galaxies fewer than other comparable sections of space. But now astronomers from the Royal Astronomical Society say they have discovered that this supervoide could not exist. They now believe that the galaxies in the cold spot are just clustered around smaller voids that populate the cold spot like bubbles. These small voids, however, cannot explain the temperature difference observed, only multiverse existence can.

This really sounds like a fun question. Let’s dive in. The word ‘parallel’ is a neat, comforting and easy to understand concept if we take the school geometry version of it of as two lines in perfect equidistance from each other.  Similarly, the word ‘universe’ is equally comforting concept if we just stick with the idea of a physical universe being a collection of rocks, elements and gases spreading outwards to physical infinity. Using both these simple definitions we might imagine ‘parallel universes’ as being lots of different physical universes that are arranged in somewhat of a parallel fashion with each other? Now even that doesn’t seem too hard to imagine either. Whether you believe it or not, the conception is easy enough. For example, I can put my shoes in shoeboxes and stick them neatly on top of each other in my wardrobe. No one box seems to interfere with the other, even though to some extent they are supporting each other. But the contents of each box remains largely unaffected by the existence of the other ‘universes’ or shoe boxes around it. The first problem with our model is if there are ‘n’ number of parallel universes then we will need ‘n’ number of shoeboxes containing ‘n’ number of universes and we very quickly run into problems imagining how big the wardrobe would need to be to fit all these universes in? So conceptually speaking it's not that we can’t imagine that there is another universe out there running parallel to our own, but moreover, how could an infinity of shoeboxes fit into our wardrobe or cosmos? The great value of this as a mental exercise is that it edges us towards a big challenge for science that holds two objects cannot take up the same parcel of space at the same time.  Our science presently has a conception of space as a mutually exclusive resource so that if a space is held by one physical object, then by definition, that space can’t be also holding another in the same position. As a species, if we become stuck in this line of thinking we will be forever stretching outwards looking for some mythical ‘boundary’ of our universe where ours ‘finishes’ and the next one ‘begins’ (the join between the shoe boxes). Instead, a more flexible science would be looking into the idea of interpenetration and developing thinking and mathematical models around how one universe or object could interpenetrate through another in the same space and for both to exist as distinct and separate physical realities.  In other words, science could consider a wardrobe that contains ‘n’ or infinite number of shoes (or universes) inside a single shoe-box. There is much more to be said here but we are out of time.

However, there are certain unexplained questions that can be neatly answered by assuming parallel universes: a) The anthropic principle: Why do certain constants in physics (such as the Gravitational constant, mass of a proton etc.) have exactly the right values. Was the Universe fine tuned by a creator to make life possible? Or do we happen to live in one of infinite universes where the values happen to be right enough, by sheer chance, for us to exist. b) Why is gravity so weak as compared to the other three fundamental forces of nature? Gravity is about ten thousand trillion trillion trillion times weaker than other forces such as the electromagnetic/Strong and weak nuclear forces. That’s the reason why you can easily lift a cup of tea with two fingers even though the entire mass of the Earth is pulling the cup down. Scientists speculate that maybe gravity leaks into higher dimensions/parallel universes and hence in our universe, it appears weak. c) Dark matter: We know that most of the matter in the universe is “dark”, as in, we can only feel its gravitational effect but cannot see it. If gravity leaks into parallel universes (which may exist in higher dimensions), it is possible that the leaking gravity from other universes is responsible for the “missing/dark matter” in our Universe.

Mae Jacolo Aguilar Apple's post in Conspiracy..and more Around 2010, scientists such as Stephen M. Feeney analyzed Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP) data and claimed to find evidence suggesting that our universe collided with other (parallel) universes in the distant past. However, a more thorough analysis of data from the WMAP and from the Planck satellite, which has a resolution 3 times higher than WMAP, did not reveal any statistically significant evidence of such a bubble universe collision In addition, there was no evidence of any gravitational pull of other universes on ours. UK’s Royal Astronomical Society, recently published a study on the so-called ‘cold spot’. This is a particularly cool patch of space seen in the radiation produced by the formation of the Universe more than 13 billion years ago. The cold spot was first glimpsed by NASA’s WMAP satellite in 2004, and then confirmed by ESA’s Planck mission in 2013. It is supremely puzzling. Most astronomers and cosmologists believe that it is highly unlikely to have been produced by the birth of the universe as it is mathematically difficult for the leading theory – which is called inflation – to explain. This latest study claims to rule out a last-ditch prosaic explanation: that the cold spot is an optical illusion produced by a lack of intervening galaxies. One of the study’s authors, Professor Tom Shanks of Durham University, told the RAS, “We can’t entirely rule out that the Spot is caused by an unlikely fluctuation explained by the standard [theory of the Big Bang]. But if that isn’t the answer, then there are more exotic explanations. Perhaps the most exciting of these is that the Cold Spot was caused by a collision between our universe and another bubble universe. If further, more detailed, analysis … proves this to be the case then the Cold Spot might be taken as the first evidence for the multiverse.”  Arguments against multiverse theories For a start, how is the existence of the other universes to be tested? To be sure, all cosmologists accept that there are some regions of the universe that lie beyond the reach of our telescopes, but somewhere on the slippery slope between that and the idea that there are an infinite number of universes, credibility reaches a limit. As one slips down that slope, more and more must be accepted on faith, and less and less is open to scientific verification. Extreme multiverse explanations are therefore reminiscent of theological discussions. Indeed, invoking an infinity of unseen universes to explain the unusual features of the one we do see is just as ad hoc as invoking an unseen Creator. The multiverse theory may be dressed up in scientific language, but in essence it requires the same leap of faith. — Paul Davies, The New York Times, "A Brief History of the Multiverse" As skeptical as I am, I think the contemplation of the multiverse is an excellent opportunity to reflect on the nature of science and on the ultimate nature of existence: why we are here.... In looking at this concept, we need an open mind, though not too open. It is a delicate path to tread. Parallel universes may or may not exist; the case is unproved. We are going to have to live with that uncertainty. Nothing is wrong with scientifically based philosophical speculation, which is what multiverse proposals are. But we should name it for what it is. — George Ellis, Scientific American, "Does the Multiverse Really Exist?"  Multiverse The multiverse is a hypothetical group of multiple separate universes including the universe in which humans live. True Science of Parallel Universes  TWO POPULAR PROPONENTS Max Tegmark and Brian Greene have devised classification schemes:  Max Erik Tegmark is a Swedish-American physicist and cosmologist. Tegmark is a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the scientific director of the Foundational Questions Institute. He is also a co-founder of the Future of Life Institute, and has received donations from Elon Musk to investigate existential risk from advanced artificial intelligence. Max Tegmark has provided a taxonomy of universes beyond the familiar observable universe in four levels: Level I: An extension of our Universe A prediction of chaotic inflation is the existence of an infinite ergodic universe, which, being infinite, must contain Hubble volumes realizing all initial conditions. Accordingly, an infinite universe will contain an infinite number of Hubble volumes, all having the same physical laws and physical constants. In regard to configurations such as the distribution of matter, almost all will differ from our Hubble volume. However, because there are infinitely many, far beyond the cosmological horizon, there will eventually be Hubble volumes with similar, and even identical, configurations. Given infinite space, there would, in fact, be an infinite number of Hubble volumes identical to ours in the universe. This follows directly from the cosmological principle, wherein it is assumed that our Hubble volume is not special or unique. Level II: Universes with different physical constants  Bubble universes – every disk represents a bubble universe. Our universe is represented by one of the disks.Universe 1 to Universe 6 represent bubble universes. Five of them have different physical constants than our universe has. In the chaotic inflation theory, which is a variant of the cosmic inflation theory, the multiverse or space as a whole is stretching and will continue doing so forever, but some regions of space stop stretching and form distinct bubbles (like gas pockets in a loaf of rising bread). Such bubbles are embryonic level I multiverses. Different bubbles may experience different spontaneous symmetry breaking, which results in different properties, such as different physical constants. Level II also includes John Archibald Wheeler's oscillatory universe theory and Lee Smolin's fecund universes theory. Level III: Many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics Hugh Everett III's many-worlds interpretation (MWI) is one of several mainstream interpretations of quantum mechanics. In brief, one aspect of quantum mechanics is that certain observations cannot be predicted absolutely. Instead, there is a range of possible observations, each with a different probability. According to the MWI, each of these possible observations corresponds to a different universe. Suppose a six-sided die is thrown and that the result of the throw corresponds to a quantum mechanics observable. All six possible ways the die can fall correspond to six different universes. Tegmark argues that a Level III multiverse does not contain more possibilities in the Hubble volume than a Level I or Level II multiverse. In effect, all the different "worlds" created by "splits" in a Level III multiverse with the same physical constants can be found in some Hubble volume in a Level I multiverse. Tegmark writes that, "The only difference between Level I and Level III is where your doppelgängers reside. In Level I they live elsewhere in good old three-dimensional space. In Level III they live on another quantum branch in infinite-dimensional Hilbert space." Similarly, all Level II bubble universes with different physical constants can, in effect, be found as "worlds" created by "splits" at the moment of spontaneous symmetry breaking in a Level III multiverse. According to Yasunori Nomura, Raphael Bousso, and Leonard Susskind, this is because global spacetime appearing in the (eternally) inflating multiverse is a redundant concept. This implies that the multiverses of Levels I, II, and III are, in fact, the same thing. This hypothesis is referred to as "Multiverse = Quantum Many Worlds". Related to the many-worlds idea are Richard Feynman's multiple histories interpretation and H. Dieter Zeh's many-minds interpretation. Level IV: Ultimate ensemble The ultimate mathematical universe hypothesis is Tegmark's own hypothesis. This level considers all universes to be equally real which can be described by different mathematical structures.  Brian Randolph Greene is an American theoretical physicist, mathematician, and string theorist. He has been a professor at Columbia University since 1996 and chairman of the World Science Festival since co-founding it in 2008. Brian Greene discussed nine types of multiverses: Quilted The quilted multiverse works only in an infinite universe. With an infinite amount of space, every possible event will occur an infinite number of times. However, the speed of light prevents us from being aware of these other identical areas. Inflationary The inflationary multiverse is composed of various pockets in which inflation fields collapse and form new universes. Brane The brane multiverse version postulates that our entire universe exists on a membrane (brane) which floats in a higher dimension or "bulk". In this bulk, there are other membranes with their own universes. These universes can interact with one another, and when they collide, the violence and energy produced is more than enough to give rise to a big bang. The branes float or drift near each other in the bulk, and every few trillion years, attracted by gravity or some other force we do not understand, collide and bang into each other. This repeated contact gives rise to multiple or "cyclic" big bangs. This particular hypothesis falls under the string theory umbrella as it requires extra spatial dimensions. Cyclic The cyclic multiverse (via the ekpyrotic scenario) has multiple branes (each a universe) that have collided, causing Big Bangs. The universes bounce back and pass through time until they are pulled back together and again collide, destroying the old contents and creating them anew. Landscape The landscape multiverse relies on string theory's Calabi–Yau spaces. Quantum fluctuations drop the shapes to a lower energy level, creating a pocket with a set of laws different from that of the surrounding space. Quantum The quantum multiverse creates a new universe when a diversion in events occurs, as in the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics. Holographic The holographic multiverse is derived from the theory that the surface area of a space can simulate the volume of the region. Simulated The simulated multiverse exists on complex computer systems that simulate entire universes. Ultimate The ultimate multiverse contains every mathematically possible universe under different laws of physics.  Reality may be made up of multiple universes, but each one may not be so different to our own, according to Stephen Hawking’s final theory of the cosmos. The term parallel universe has, I believe, been used to refer to entire self-contained universes that are “sealed off” from other such universes. Our universe would merely be one of possibly an infinite* number of them. *Doctor Stephen Hawking’s last paper he published before his recent death didn’t totally refute the existence of parallel universes, but did posit that if they existed, there would be fewer of them than others have postulated, and certainly not an infinite number of them. The term has been used to refer to universes that arise through different physical processes: arising from so-called eternal inflation**; a phenomena of the “many worlds” interpretation of Quantum Mechanics; pockets of our own universe that can never be reached or contacted. “Alternate Universe” is also a term I’ve seen to refer to them. This is not to be confused with additional dimensions (part and parcel of our universe). **I believe this, and maybe the 3rd type of multiple universes I mentioned is (are?) the only type(s) where the laws of nature could be different from the laws we have discerned for our universe. The problem with these scientce-based hunches is that there is no way known of to directly verify their existence, and to my knowledge efforts to find indirect evidence have not yielded any compelling results.

I do not. I don’t believe they don’t exist either. Parallel universes are hypothetical entities. Physics doesn’t supply any proof of that hypothesis or exclude their possibility. The multiverse is conjectured as a solution to certain features of the universe but it is not the only possible solution, nor is it an overwhelming candidate. Belief is what you accord to something that you feel compelled to accept regardless of the lack of immediate proof. Where there are strong proofs, you can accept a paradigm without according it belief status. I accept the laws of motion, for example. They don’t require my belief. Where the argument is statistical or implied by logic, one enters into the realm of belief. People with religious beliefs are convinced by the logic of a creation requiring a creator. I don’t find that logic compelling (or even that the universe warrants the ‘creation’ label), hence our beliefs (mine and the theists’) differ. I do believe that life is most likely a feature of the cosmos and not just isolated to Earth because of the speed with which life emerged here (as soon as it could); the ordinariness of planets like ours (we find new exoplanets every day circling distant stars in similar orbits); and the vastness of the cosmos (there are 250 billion ± 150 billion stars in our galaxy alone, a significant percentage with solar systems, and trillions of galaxies in the observable universe; that’s roughly 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 stars that might, like ours, support living planets). Logic and statistics converge and prompt me to believe something that lacks unequivocal proof. Back to parallel universes then. The logic that makes them a necessary feature of cosmology is not compelling—it’s just convenient, an alternative to other explanations that are no more or less compelling/convenient. When a persuasive argument for parallel universes arises, I’ll take up that belief.

A parallel universe is a hypothetical self-contained reality co-existing with one's own. A specific group of parallel universes are called a "multiverse", although this term can also be used to describe the possible parallel universes that constitute reality. While the terms "parallel universe" and "alternative reality" are generally synonymous and can be used interchangeably in most cases, there is sometimes an additional connotation implied with the term "alternative reality" that implies that the reality is a variant of our own. The term "parallel universe" is more general, without any connotations implying a relationship, or lack of relationship, with our own universe. A universe where the very laws of nature are different – for example, one in which there are no Laws of Motion – would in general count as a parallel universe but not an alternative reality and a concept between both fantasy world and earth. The actual quantum-mechanical hypothesis of parallel universes is "universes that are separated from each other by a single quantum event." I want you to check this link. The notion of another world, just like this one, with a reality different from ours does not exist only in fiction – science is also familiar with and is looking into the concept of multiple universes. It is possible that within what we call time and space, other dimensions with alternative realities exist. Sometimes those realities vary slightly and sometimes they differ radically. Infinite universe – infinite possibilities The first idea of parallel universes says that since space is so huge the rules of probability entail that other planets just like Earth exist. As a matter of fact, if the universe is infinite it must have infinitely many planets. Some of them, in all probability, would have almost the same events to those on Earth occurring within or on them. The reason we can’t see these other universes is because our cosmic vision is defined and limited by the ultimate speed of light. Since light started traveling when Big Bang occurred (cca 14 billion years ago) we can’t see past 14 billion light-years. This volume of space known as the Hubble volume represents the universe we can observe.  Bubble expansion The second idea suggests that regions of space are in a continuous inflation phase. Due to the ongoing inflationary phase in these universes, the area between us and the other universes is expanding faster than the speed of light which also makes them completely unreachable. The quantum fluctuations in the initial universe’s vacuum energy produced bubble universes everywhere, expanding at different rates. When inflation starts, it generates not just one, but an infinite number of universes. Possibilities built-in the quantum wavefunction The third idea comes from the many worlds interpretation (MWI) from quantum physics in which every quantum possibility built-in in the quantum wavefunction evolves into a real possibility in some alternate reality. When thinking of a “parallel universe”, the average person is probably thinking of this type of universe. The main difference from other types of universes mentioned previously is that these take place at the same time and within the same place as our own, but there is still no way of accessing them. These types of universes are determined by moments in our lives and decisions we make that cause a split of your “now” self into a limitless number of future selves, all of which are oblivious to the fact that the other one exists. Mathematically possible is probable The fourth (and most debated) idea follows essentially different mathematical laws of nature than our universe. In a nutshell, any universe that physicists can make work on paper must exist if we follow the mathematical democracy principle which states that each universe that is mathematically possible has the same possibility of truly existing.

One of my former students, who is now an FBI agent specializing in fraud, pointed out to me years ago that one of the most common symptoms of pseudoscience was the obsessive use of fantasy themes from science fiction and space opera stories, often dating back many decades. [As the population grew more and more illiterate, the references tended to be from movies and TV series, rather than printed fiction.] The “parallel world” theme was invented by Murray Leinster, in a story called SIDEWISE IN TIME, from ASTOUNDING STORIES, June 1934. There are no parallel worlds in physics or astronomy. This use of fantasy themes in journalism and publicity supposedly involving actual science, as in “quantum teleportation,” etc., etc., etc., does far more harm to the public understanding of science than can be ever repaired, by any means.

There are at least five theories why a multiverse is possible 1. Infinite universes. We don't know what the shape of space-time is exactly. One prominent theory is that it is flat and goes on forever. This would present the possibility of many universes being out there. But with that topic in mind, it's possible that universes can start repeating themselves. That's because particles can only be put together in so many ways. More about that in a moment. 2. Bubble universes. Another theory for multiple universes comes from "eternal inflation." Based on research from Tufts University cosmologist Alexander Vilenkin, when looking at space-time as a whole, some areas of space stop inflating like the Big Bang inflated our own universe. Others, however, will keep getting larger. So if we picture our own universe as a bubble, it is sitting in a network of bubble universes of space. What's interesting about this theory is the other universes could have very different laws of physics than our own, since they are not linked. 3. Daughter universes. Or perhaps multiple universes can follow the theory of quantum mechanics (how subatomic particles behave), as part of the "daughter universe" theory. If you follow the laws of probability, it suggests that for every outcome that could come from one of your decisions, there would be a range of universes — each of which saw one outcome come to be. So in one universe, you took that job to China. In another, perhaps you were on your way and your plane landed somewhere different, and you decided to stay. And so on. 4. Mathematical universes. Another possible avenue is exploring mathematical universes, which, simply put, explain that the structure of mathematics may change depending in which universe you reside. "A mathematical structure is something that you can describe in a way that's completely independent of human baggage," said theory-proposer Max Tegmark of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as quoted in the 2012 article. "I really believe that there is this universe out there that can exist independently of me that would continue to exist even if there were no humans." 5. Parallel universes. And last but not least as the idea of parallel universes. Going back to the idea that space-time is flat, the number of possible particle configurations in multiple universes would be limited to 10^10^122 distinct possibilities, to be exact. So, with an infinite number of cosmic patches, the particle arrangements within them must repeat — infinitely many times over. This means there are infinitely many "parallel universes": cosmic patches exactly the same as ours (containing someone exactly like you), as well as patches that differ by just one particle's position, patches that differ by two particles' positions, and so on down to patches that are totally different from ours.

Where did the idea of parallel universe where time flows backwards come from?  Well, in 2006 and 2014 NASA did an experiment where a high-tech, stratospheric balloon detected very rare radio waves coming up from Earth’s surface instead of the horizon. This was highly unusual and created enough excitement that the experiment was written up in the New Scientist, where it was argued that these signals required the existence of an upside -down universe coming into existence at the same time ’i.e. the big bang’ as the universe we live existing in parallel with ours. Only this year did it spill into the headlines again, but what are the underlying facts? Thanks to the diligent probing and fact checking by Jamie Carter and Ethan Siegel of Forbes, we can put the idea of a parallel universe to rest. Read this research here on how the rumours of a parallel universe got started: Has NASA Found A Parallel Universe ‘Where Time Flows Backwards?’ The Truth Behind The Headlines and Ask Ethan: Have We Finally Found Evidence For A Parallel Universe? We almost were had.

Honestly nobody knows. The idea originated as an interpretation of quantum mechanics and it has some appeal because having an infinite number of universes in superposition  avoids having to figure out what makes wave functions collapse.  Quantum superposition is definitely real, but c'mon now. Leaping from fuzzy electrons to fuzzy universes takes a colossal suspension of disbelief. There is no way to prove or disprove it, so the theory is philosophy not physics. And besides, physicists are far too glib with infinity. Any theory that depends on an infinite number of physical things, whether atoms or universes, is probably nonsense.

There is probably no way to know if parallel universes are really real — we can only know if they are mathematically possible, since nobody has yet proposed a means outside of science fiction to access one. Mathematically, yes it is possible, but it is mathematically just as possible that they are not real. There is math which works either way. To a degree, we don’t yet know where to look, either. It’s sort of like the question of whether the possibility of mating with an alien species is real — well, sure, IF we can find an alien species and IF we can line up our DNA with theirs (or whatever they have), and so forth.

response.answer_text: A high probability: Yes. Following the rules of Quantum Theory, there is a possibility for everything and anything to happen. This automatically means that there must be parallel universes, where different outcomes of different events are taking place. For example, a cat touches a live wire in our universe, and dies, then there will be another universe where it will be severely injured, another where it is totally safe, and infinite others where cat doesn't even exist. Though how do these parallel universes exist is still speculative. There might be an infinite matrix of universes, or they may exist in outer space simultaneously. For understanding how they may exist in a matrix, we can assume that atom, or a subatomic particles consists of a universe. Technically, we too would be in such a subatomic universe, and the chain would continue infinitely in both directions. For understanding parallel universes, humans would have to either understand things at the micro level, or at the macro level to a great extent.

It's been further been speculated that Gravity maybe leaking into those extra-dimensional planes beyond the known 3 spatial dimensions.  If so this would be noticed as a deviation from the square-law variation of Gravity with distance. A deviation from the square-law variation of Gravity maybe an indication of extra-dimensional planes, and possibly an indication of parallel universes.

The answer of modern science to this question is: Maybe. Parallel universes are not impossible (or the idea would have been rejected by science already), and they would provide handy explanations for some phenomena of physics, including quantum physics. But that’s not the same as saying they are a thing, and at this point there’s no or almost no evidence pointing at their existence. Scientists are struggling to think of ways they could prove or disprove parallel universes. Thinking on this topic is still very much up in the air. Does parallel universe exist at all? Parallel universe is a conceptual reality, a reality that is theoretically in conformity with our current picture of the universe, without contradicting any known law. It is mathematically consistent with the current theoretical world picture of physics. In fact there could be several parallel universes. But there has not been any empirical confirmation of parallel universes. In some ways, this is impossible even in principle. By definition, if we can observe such a thing it would be part of our universe. That is why they are called parallel: They will never intersect. In a sense it may be compared to the God concept of religions, which is in accordance with the worldviews of religions but which seems to be beyond the reach of our observational faculties. So, in principle, it is impossible to answer this question one way or another. It is somewhat like the question (but not the same as): “Do civilizations exist in some remote galaxy? you can answer Yes, and you can answer No, without ever knowing if you are right or wrong. Rarely have physics and metaphysics been so interlinked as in the matter of parallel universes. But, as with the scholastics and the question of how many angelic ballerinas can frolic on a pinhead, the subject is exciting, fascinating, and journal-articles- provoking, but with very little possibility of a telescopic aha experience, even of the antenna kind. 5 Sept 2017

No prediction of anything related to Parallel Universe have been confirmed. So, Hypothesize the there is a Parallel Universe is a bad idea.

Hugh Everette’s “many worlds” is the usual idea referred to when talking about “parallel universes”. It is an idea sent to explain single photon or single electron interference. The idea is something like on the TV show “Sliders” where there are alternate timelines in parallel. E.g. a world where Hitler got to study Art instead of conquering Europe. The idea (or something much like it) is very likely true. Quantum “consistent histories” and “many minds” are related ideas. Modal Logic’s “possible worlds” semantics / math also relates. Many worlds are examples of multiverse theories. Technically multiverse theories involve many parallel worlds. M-Theory and Loop Gravity are examples of models involving multiple universes forming a multiverse. The complexity of the design of our universe and the optimization for maximal numbers of black holes are evidence of multiple universes. Other evidence exists. Einstein’s Relativity theories also imply multiple universes. Every time you change direction or speed you enter a different inertial frame which is effectively a different world. The worlds however seem so similar that we are unaware.

One of the problems with single universes in philosophy is the problem of what created the initial cause or what underpins the base foundations. Another problem is the cause of coincidences or fine tuning. In our universe the fine tuning or complexity is so refined that we normally assume some kind of design, evolution and/or selection is involved. The nature of fine tuning in our universe leads itself to some element of design or evolution. E.g. If many random universes we would have to assume that more universes seem designed than ones that don’t. But we have competing ideas of Entropy and Evolution. If we assume no laws of physics we would assume more messy or non-viable worlds and those worlds that are viable are more likely to seem badly designed. Evolution (or other progressive forces) exist in our universe. Given a progressive force we would assume over time one or more super entities somewhat similar to gods should eventually evolve. Such development would likely take much longer than the billion of years since our big bang. We can safely assume some complexity or design was in place setting up our big bang. Such complexity can happen through multiple bang theories. It can partly be assumed in multiple world models but more likely a mix of multiple universes and some kind of Evolution is more likely. Lee Smolin’s Baby Universes idea is one such model that fits this description.

response.answer_text: A parallel universe (should it be proven) wouldn't be observable as would looking in a mirror at a parallel reflection of you. Even if all parallel universes were an exact copy of this universe, it would be difficult to prove.

Well, fairly obviously, it is not summat we can observe or test. If there is a separate alternative, then it will, by definition, be outside our universe and hence beyond us in every possible way. I am not sure we are sure such things exist in any case. Infinitely branching universes was regarded as an absurd conclusion of quantum uncertainty. The thermodynamics make no sense, and I don’t think it was ever meant to be taken seriously. Alternative or parallel universes of similar age to ours are among the wilder proposals of string theory, in particular -brane theory where the collision between membranes in some unimaginable space-like existence are the cause of the big bang. These ideas are a long way from mainstream, and would appear to be absolutely untestable, and making no worthwhile predictions. We can barely see or understand our own universe. If there are others they are, by definition, closed to us, so not worth worrying about. Dull stuff, really.

I personally don't think we are the only universe and I have a certain degree of logic to at least indicate this. We live in a finely tuned universe; the physical constants which form the foundation of the mathematics which govern our reality are set at very precise values. If these values were to change even slightly, stars wouldn't have formed, so neither would planets or life. The probability of there being a single universe with constants of absolutely perfect values to produce life are infinitesimal. Realistically there's 4 possibilities. Either… There is one universe and the physical constants by extremely small chances happen to be perfect to produce life (the chances of this probability are extremely small).There are many or infinite universes with a variety of physical constants and we obviously are born into one with the correct constant values (this seems to me more likely and makes more sense).There is a God or intelligent designed that set the constants at their perfect values.There is a single universe that explodes into existence, then eventually dies, only to be re-born again with different constants and laws. This cycle has been happening over and over until a universe with the correct constants and laws to produce life spawned into existence.To me the multiverse option makes the most sense. There seem to be some current theories in modern physics suggesting this too.

response.answer_text: It makes a certain amount of sense to consider that there might exist parallel universes.  No one knows whether the big bang that kickstarted our universe originated in some mother universe, or whether daughter universes can originate from ours - perhaps within black holes - on and on.  As to whether there's any way to communicate or even detect parallel universes, if they exist, it's unlikely.  Remember, within a black hole, and presumably before the big bang occurred, time was frozen; there was no such thing as our version of time until the big bang occurred.  Every other universe also has its own version of spacetime, presumably completely divorced from ours.  Theoretically two universes could intersect, I suppose, but who knows?  So there's no practical reason to think about parallel universes, but it's kind of fun.

I am not cosmologist, but I doubt the existence of parallel universes is provable. My understanding is that they have been postulated simply to get around the issue of why matter is exactly the way it needs to be for our universe to exist at all. For example, why there is more matter than anti-matter and why the fundemental forces are what they are. Parallel universes circuvent this by each having different physical constants and hence not making our universe “special” any more. Indeed, that there may be an infinity of universes each with different physical constants. My personal belief is that this question is answered by the Weak Anthropic Principle and does not require the existence of parallel universes (which are intuitively not right anyway). Losely stated the Weak Anthropic Principle answers the question “Why are we here?” with “If it had been any other way, we would not be asking the question.”

Mathematically parallel universes can be described. In reality? Nobody knows. It's impossible (with our current technology) to determine if they exist. We can't detect them. We can't measure them nor do we see any evidence of parallel universes interacting with our universe. We have absolutely zero evidence they exist. First of all let me make some things clear . A theory is something which enables us predictability in experiments and can explain a lot of phenomena around us , as long as it does that , it's not wrong , even if it's not completely correct . Now parallel universes would be of two types . There are two theories for that . Some , that there were infinite parallel universes from the beginning , and in each of them there's an exact version of us from the beginning , living their own life , wondering maybe this question right now . And there is this multiverse theory , which says that at each point of life , the universe diverges according to the numerous decisions we could have taken . Nobody knows, and it is not testable, at least with present or foreseeable technology. The theory, as I understand it, states that the odds of our particular universe emerging from the conditions of the Big Bang, with matter as we know it to include stars, galaxies, and in at least one planetary system with macroscopic intelligent life, are astronomically small. Therefore, as a matter of mathematical probability, it is likely that our universe is only one manifestation of an almost infinite number of possible outcomes from a Big Bang type event.

Nobody knows, and it’s not clear if we ever will know, or even if it will be possible to find out. As far as “parallel universes” theory goes, the two main ones (I think) are Hugh Everett’s “Many Worlds” theory, in which there is a universe for every possible quantum event ever, and String Theory’s “Braneworlds”, which has completely seperate universes existing like sheets of paper (or membranes, which is where “Brane” comes from) in some higher dimensional space. There are plenty more theories for alternative universes, and the “metaverse” in general, but the above are the most “parallel” ones. I’ve not yet heard of any testable hypotheses. I’ve seen speculation like “Well, someday it may be possible to test this theory but we can’t at the moment”. For an overview of metaverse theories, I’d highly recommend Brian Greene’s book The Hidden Reality.
